details.title: A novel approach to determine minimal tie-sets of complex network

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Electr. Eng., Sharif Univ. of Technol., Tehran, Iran

p: M. Fotuhi-Firuzabad (Senior Member, 99) was born in Iran. Obtained B.Sc. and M.Sc. Degrees in Electrical Engineering from Sharif University of Technology and Tehran University in 1986 and 1989 respectively and M.Sc. and Ph.D. Degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Saskatchewan in 1993 and 1997 respectively. Dr. Fotuhi-Firuzabad worked as a postdoctoral fellow in the Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Saskatchewan from Jan. 1998 to Sept. 2000 and from Sept. 2001 to Sept. 2002 where he conducted research in the area of power system reliability. He worked as an assistant professor in the same department from Sept. 2000 to Sept. 2001. Presently he is an associate professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran.

authors.name: M. Fotuhi-Firuzabad

p: R. Billinton (F'78) came to Canada from England in 1952. He obtained B.Sc. and M.Sc. Degrees from the University of Manitoba and Ph.D. and D.Sc. Degrees from the University of Saskatchewan. Roy worked for Manitoba Hydro in the System Planning and Production Divisions. He joined the University of Saskatchewan in 1964 where he is currently professor emeritus in the Electrical Engineering department. Dr. Billinton is a Fellow of the IEEE, the EIC, and the Royal Society of Canada; and a Professional Engineer in the Province of Saskatchewan.

T. S. Munian (Student Member, 2001) was born in India. She obtained the B.Tech. Degree in Electrical Engineering from Pondicherry University, India, in 1998. She obtained her M.Sc. degree from the University of Saskatchewan, Canada. She is presently a Ph.D. student in the Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Western Ontario, Canada.

B. Vinayagam (Student Member, 2001) was born in India. He obtained the B.Tech. Degree in Electrical Engineering from Pondicherry University, India, in 1997. He obtained his M.Sc. degree from the University of Saskatchewan, Canada. He is presently a Ph.D. student in the Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Western Ontario, Canada.

details.abstract: Network reliability analysis is usually based on minimal path or cut enumeration from which the associated reliability expressions are deduced. The cut-set method is a popular approach in the reliability analysis of many systems from simple to complex configurations. The computational requirements necessary to determine the minimal cut-sets of a network depend mainly on the number of minimal paths between the source and the sink. A technique designated as the "Path Tracing Algorithm" is presented in this paper, which can handle both simple and complex networks, and considers both unidirectional and bi-directional branches. A step by step procedure is explained using a bridge-network. The algorithm is easy to program, and does not require limits on the size of the network. The applicability of the proposed technique is illustrated by application to a more complicated system.

references.title: Probabilistic Risk Assessment and Management for Engineers and Scientists

context.text: A range of reliability measures are described in the literature [1]–[5].

context.text: A range of reliability measures are described in the literature [1]–[2][5].

references.title: On the behavior of failure bounds

context.text: A range of reliability measures are described in the literature [1]–[3][5].

links.abstract: The behaviour of failure frequency bounds has been studied in this paper. The alternate bounds are indeed upper and lower bounds to the failure frequency. These bounds can diverge at intermediate steps though they finally converge to the exact value. The divergent behaviour is likely to occur when ¿/¿ is relatively large. It is preferrable to use the margin between fUimin and fLimax, rather than between fUi and fLi as the criterion for truncating the computations.

references.text: C. Singh, "On the behavior of failure bounds", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-26, pp. 63-66, April 1977.

references.title: System Reliability Modeling and Evaluation

context.text: A range of reliability measures are described in the literature [1]–[4][5].
A minimal cut-set is one in which all the components must fail in order for the system to fail [4], [12], and if any one element does not fail then the system does not fail.

Assuming component independence, and denoting the probability of failure of cut-set \$C_{i}\$ by \$P(\overline {C_{i} })\$, the probabilities of the system failure (unavailability) for \$m\$ minimal cut-sets are given by [4]: .

Assuming component independence, and denoting the probability of occurrence of tie-set \$T_{i}\$ by \$P(\overline {T_{i} })\$, the probability of the system success (availability) for \$n\$ minimal tie-sets are given by [4]: .
The cut-sets and tie-sets can be developed from the event trees [4].

references.text: C. Singh, R. Billinton, System Reliability Modeling and Evaluation, 1977, Hutchinson Educational.

references.title: Reliability Evaluation of Engineering Systems: Concepts and Techniques

context.text: A range of reliability measures are described in the literature [1]–[5].
It is also very difficult to implement in a computer program [5].

This method has been used widely for many years in the reliability evaluation of both stand-by & mission oriented systems, where a particular failure condition is considered, and a tree is constructed which identifies the various combinations and sequences of other failures leading to the failure being considered [5].
Another approach to deduce the network minimal cuts is to first find out the cut-sets of each path, and then combine them with those of other paths in all possible ways [5].
The result gives paths only between the two nodes of interest [5].
The final result gives the paths between all the pairs of nodes [5].
Once the minimal paths are found, the minimal cut sets are determined by constructing an incidence matrix from the minimal paths, and combining the columns of the incidence matrix [5].

references.text: R. Billinton, R. Allan, Reliability Evaluation of Engineering Systems: Concepts and Techniques, 1994, Plenum Press.

references.title: Reliability Evaluation of Power Systems

context.text: The cut-set method is very popular in the reliability analysis of many applications, from general systems to specific systems such as power distribution networks [6].

references.text: R. Billinton, R. N. Allan, Reliability Evaluation of Power Systems, 1996, Plenum Press.

references.title: Cutset analysis of networks using basic minimal paths and network decomposition

context.text: The computational requirements to determine the minimal cut-sets of a network mainly depend on the number of minimal paths between the source and the sink [7].

links.abstract: The concept of basic minimal paths has been introduced, and its use in deducing the node cutsets of a network was described. This 3 paper deals with two important aspects of basic minimal paths: 1) the deduction of link cutsets from node cutsets, and 2) reduction of computational requirements in deducing the basic minimal paths using network decomposition.

references.text: G. B. Jasmon, "Cutset analysis of networks using basic minimal paths and network decomposition", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-34, pp. 303-307, October 1985.

references.title: A new technique in minimal path and cut-set evaluation

links.abstract: This paper presents a new technique for deducing the minimal paths and cutsets of a general network. A powerful concept of reducing the total number of minimal paths to its basic minimal paths is introduced. This concept reduces the computational time and required storage in deducing the minimal cutsets. A new technique for evaluating minimal cutsets has been adopted. Examples demonstrate the power of the technique in reducing the computational requirements as compared to the conventional method...

references.text: G. B. Jasmon, O. S. Kal, "A new technique in minimal path and cut-set evaluation", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-34, pp. 136-143, June 1985.

links.abstract: A method is suggested for determining the minimal cuts and paths of a general network with common-cause failures. The minimal paths (cuts) are deduced from simple network minimal paths (cuts) obtained for the network if the common-cause failures are ignored, by appropriate manipulations with sets of path (cut) branches and sets of branches interrupted by common-cause failures. Calculation procedures are presented for an effective application of the method, to evaluate the reliability indices of ...

references.title: A computer program for approximating system reliability

context.text: A minimal cut-set is one in which all the components must fail in order for the system to fail [4], [12], and if any one element does not fail then the system does not fail.
A tie-set will fail if just one component of the tie-set fails and all the system tie-sets must fail for the system to fail [12].
Having the minimal paths, one way to determine the minimal cuts is to construct an incidence matrix, and combine the columns of that matrix [12].

links.abstract: A computer program, which provides bounds for system reliability, is described. The algorithms are based on the concepts of success paths and cut sets. A listing of the elements in the system, their predecessors, and the probability of successful operation of each element are the inputs. The outputs are the success paths, the cut sets, and a series of upper and lower reliability bounds; these bounds converge to the reliability which would be calculated if all the terms in the model were evaluate...

references.text: A. C. Nelson, J. R. Batts, R. L. Beadles, "A computer program for approximating system reliability", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-19, pp. 61-65, 1970.

references.title: An algorithm to find minimal cuts of coherent fault-trees with event-classes using a decision tree

context.text: Fault trees are very popular tools in reliability engineering [13], and use a logic which is essentially the reverse of that used in event trees.

[13] presents an algorithm designated as CS-MS in which the input events of the fault tree are divided into different classes where events of the same class are indistinguishable. [16] introduces an approach for identifying minimal cut-sets in a fault tree by first developing a virtual cut-set tree structure, and then traversing the cut-set tree a number of times in a systematic manner.

links.abstract: A new algorithm, the Carrasco-Sune minimal cuts (CS-MC) algorithm for computing the minimal cuts of s-coherent fault trees is presented. Input events of the fault tree are assumed classified into classes, where events of the same class are indistinguishable. This allows capturing some symmetries which some systems exhibit. CS-MC uses a decision tree. The search implemented by the decision tree is guided by heuristics which try to make the CS-MC algorithm as efficient as possible. In addition, an...

references.text: J. A. Carrasco, V. Sune, "An algorithm to find minimal cuts of coherent fault-trees with event-classes using a decision tree", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 48, pp. 31-41, March 1999.

references.title: Efficient construction of minimal cutsets from fault trees

context.text: A fault tree is a logical representation, identifying all event sequences through which faults of single components affect the failure of the entire system [14].
The repeated secondary events are then reduced [14].

links.abstract: A formal method and an algorithm are presented to determine minimal cut sets (MCSs) from fault trees. The method is based upon segmenting the tree, constructing MCSs of subtrees and subsequent expanding into the MCS of the original tree. The major advantage of the method is the direct determination of MCSs up to any order required. More particularly, the algorithm DICOMICS allows straightforward analyses for all those cases (large trees, high order cut sets, repeated elements) where present comb...

references.text: S. Garriba, P. Mussio, F. Naldi, G. Reina, G. Volta, "Efficient construction of minimal cutsets from fault trees", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-26, pp. 88-93, 1977.

references.title: A computer scientist looks at reliability computations

context.text: It is, however, not easy to deduce all the minimal cut-sets of an arbitrary fault tree as the complexity of the network increases [15].

links.abstract: Some kinds of fault tree analysis are described for which cut set enumeration is inadequate. Modularization leads to more efficient computer programs, and also identifies subsystems which are intuitively meaningful. The problem of finding all modules of a fault tree is formulated as as extension of the problem of finding all ``cut-points'' of an undirected graph. The major result is a FORTRAN program (available as a Supplement) which can find modules of a 1000-event fault tree in a small fractio...

references.text: A. Rosenthal, "A computer scientist looks at reliability computations", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-29, pp. 136-138, June 1980.

references.title: An efficient computational technique for evaluating the cut/tie sets and common-cause failures of complex systems

context.text: These paths contain the components which must work, or the events which must occur together, to achieve system success [17].

links.abstract: The paper describes a new and efficient approach to the cut/tie set and common-cause failure analysis for use with event tree or similar methodologies. The computational techniques have been developed for use by engineers during the design stage of a system, and computing efficiency is emphasized. The storage rquired for the cut/tie set analysis is the absolute minimum, i.e., only one path need be known and stored at a time. The storage required for the common-cause failure analysis is minimised...

references.text: R. N. Allan, I. L. Rondiris, D. M. Fryer, "An efficient computational technique for evaluating the cut/tie sets and common-cause failures of complex systems", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. R-30, pp. 101-109, 1981.

patentCitations.patentAbstract: A computer-implemented method of technology mapping a circuit design for implementation within a programmable logic device can include determining a plurality of cut sets for the circuit design, wherein each cut set includes a plurality of cuts. The method can include evaluating each cut set according to a cost function that depends, at least in part, upon a measure of inter-cut symmetry and selecting a cut set according to the cost function. Each cut of the selected cut set can represent an instantiation of at least one logic component within the programmable logic device. The circuit design specifying the selected cut set can be output.
patentCitations.title: Function symmetry-based optimization for physical synthesis of programmable integrated circuits
patentCitations.inventors: Jang, Tetse; Chan, Vi Chi; Chung, Kevin

patentCitations.patentAbstract: A computer-implemented method of improving timing of a circuit design for a programmable logic device can include identifying a timing critical wire of the circuit design and determining a fanout free cone coupled to a plurality of leaf nodes, wherein the critical wire links a critical leaf node of the plurality of leaf nodes with the fanout free cone. At least one leaf node set can be selected, wherein the leaf node set includes a plurality of symmetric leaf nodes including the critical leaf node and at least one non-critical leaf node. At least two leaf nodes of a leaf node set can be swapped in the circuit design. The circuit design can be output.
patentCitations.title: SYMMETRY BASED OPTIMIZATION FOR THE PHYSICAL SYNTHESIS OF PROGRAMMABLE LOGIC DEVICES
